0.09.text: With over two-decades of experience with gender issues she’s actively involved in public speaking

5.10.text:
in writing and educating Focus constituents on a 
wide variety of subjects related to homosexuality.

12.80.text:
Prior to joining Focus, Melisa served as Executive
Director of an Exodus Member Ministry in Kentucky.

19.40.text:
She holds a Masters of Divinity
from Asbury Theological Seminary.

24.20.text: Please welcome with me, Melisa Fryrear.

35.00.text:
Good morning. We are so grateful to have each
of you with us today and I want you to know

42.41.text:
how earnestly we have been praying for all
of you and for our time together today.

52.00.text:
Almost 20 years ago now I was sitting in a
living room with a number of lesbian friends and we

58.90.text: were talking about the continuum of sexuality. And what I mean about the continuum of sexuality are the variances

69.00.text: between heterosexuality, bisexuality, homosexuality and transsexuality.

77.20.text: And at one point in the conversation I quickly stood up and boldly proclaimed among the woman -- "I don't know

84.20.text: about anyone else here tonight, but I’m 99.9 percent gay and that's all there is to it."

94.20.text: 99.9 percent gay. The scales were a bit tipped, yes?

102.80.text: Well I’m going to share about that remaining tenth of a percentage point a little bit later and I wanted to begin

109.80.text: with that story because I want to ask you to keep in your mind that picture of a scale and the cause and effect

117.20.text: relationship that one side has over the other all related to the degree of weight.

124.80.text: Let me begin with this very important comment:

131.00.text: Female Homosexuality is a complex condition, it’s a complex struggle -- maybe because women. (Laughter)

146.20.text: I could probably get away with saying that because thankfully now I know that I am one!

154.00.text: Been a journey but I’ve secured that part. So maybe because women tend to be a bit complex --

162.00.text:
maybe that translates to this struggle as well.
I want to offer this observation as well.

169.80.text:
In almost 15 years in this area of ministry I have
met hundreds of women overcoming lesbianism

177.80.text: and what I find interesting is that although each woman’s experience is unique to her, there do seem

185.60.text: to be a number of common influencing factors in may of their lives.

191.00.text: The official statement of the American Psychiatric Associations fact sheet on gay, lesbian and bisexual issues states:

199.00.text: “There are no replicated scientific studies supporting any specific biological ideology for homosexuality."

207.92.text: And as Christians who hold to a biblical worldview, we do not believe that people are born gay.

215.40.text: And so what I’d to do in the time that we have is to offer for your consideration what we have found in our

223.60.text: experience to be the most common influencing factors for many women who struggle with same-sex attraction.

234.00.text: Let me mention also an aspect of sexuality that seems distinctive to women.

241.80.text:
And that is fluidity or a fluctuation
in sexual identities, attractions and behaviors.

251.66.text:
Dr. Lisa Diamond of the University of Utah
conducted a study, it was later published

258.28.text:
in Developmental Psychology and she found
that many women are not exclusive in their

264.63.text:
attractions – a particularly bisexually
identified or lesbian identified woman.

270.40.text:
Rather she found there can be a broad fluctuation
of sexual identities throughout the course

276.16.text:
of a woman’s life. Her conclusions were
supported when she did a follow-up study --

281.46.text:
a follow-up report a couple of years later,
when she found that over half of the women

287.61.text:
had changed their sexual identity more than
once in just the two-year time since the original study.

295.80.text:
She commented “Western culture expects sexuality to
come in one neat package when often that is not the case."

304.80.text: And again this is referencing bisexually identified or lesbian identified women in particular.

312.60.text: I want to mention some variations of same sex behavior among women as well.

319.00.text:
And these are pretty well self-defined.  I'll mention
three but I want to spend more time on the fourth one.

325.94.text:
The first one is Same-Sex Experimentation.
You know as a Kentucky girl, public school

333.01.text:
educated, that’s a little hard to roll out
-- Same-Sex Experimentation, but I think I

337.45.text:
got that out without anything maybe flying
on the front row, so I appreciate that – maybe duck.

343.40.text:
And you should have heard when I tried
to say that when I had braces on my teeth.

347.52.text:
Of one reason I got braces is I shared with
my orthodontist that I wanted to have a smile

352.79.text:
that genuinely reflected my personality – straight.
Get it? They both have been a journey.

371.57.text:
Oh I digress. Same-sex experimentation:
This describes a women who is experimenting, again self-defined

380.40.text:
– this is a women who doesn’t embrace lesbianism
as an identity but as experimenting or dabbling

387.20.text:
if you will in these experiences with other women.
The second we call Emotional Enmeshment.

395.00.text:
Now this describes a woman who
would never physically act out with another

399.70.text:
woman but often times because she has no sense
of personal identity, has no sense of who

405.94.text:
she is as a person, she’s relying on another
woman often times to gain that sense of identity

411.35.text:
for herself and that sense of well-being.
And so Emotionally Enmeshed are codependent.

419.00.text:
The third we could label, and the names keep changing:
Generation X, Generation Y, Generation Next

426.80.text:
and what is it now, Millennial Generation?
I can’t keep up with it, it’s changing too quickly.

431.00.text:
But I’m trying to describe a younger woman.
This woman again usually is heterosexually identified,

437.20.text:
she’s attracted to men and yet she's 
engaging in these same-sex behaviors.

442.70.text:
Now as we talk with young women these are
some of the reasons as to why they’re doing this.

448.40.text:
Some woman, again heterosexually
identified, they’re attracted to men and

453.63.text:
yet they’re trying to draw his attention
by engaging in this same-sex behavior.

458.80.text:
We've had these horrific reality dating shows like
"Elimidate" and "The Fifth Wheel" that promote

465.60.text:
sexual behavior between the women. And I’m
not trying to be crass because that what the

470.92.text:
men are attracted to and so the young women
are engaging in that same-sex behavior to

476.01.text:
try and gain his attention. We’ve talked
with other young women for whom simply sexual

482.87.text:
boundaries don’t exist and so when she’s
confronted with this situation perhaps someone

487.88.text:
like me years ago who crossed her path, perhaps
she’s confronted with this situation without

493.45.text:
those sexual boundaries in place, she sees
no reason to refuse that advance whether it’s

498.70.text:
a man or a woman. We’re finding among younger
people today as well that it’s in Vogue

505.08.text:
or Chic to be crossing over these gender and
boundary lines and engaging in same-sex behavior.

513.36.text: And the work that we do in our Gender Division in Public Policy, we’re seeing a dramatic increase in the

519.00.text: number of younger women, again crossing over these gender, and I’m getting the head nods,

523.80.text:
crossing over these gender and boundary
sexual lines and engaging in same-sex behaviors.

529.40.text:
The secular press has picked up on it too.
In 2006 in the fall, CBS News cited

535.35.text:
a Centers for Disease Control report which
stated “More American women – particularly

540.85.text:
those in their late teens and 20’s – are
experimenting with bisexuality or at least

546.23.text:
feel more comfortable reporting same-sex encounters.”
Some sexuality experts say that it’s even

553.90.text:
more likely that many younger women simply see this
as a rite of passage in her young adult years.

561.80.text:
The trend among some college
women in particular has prompted sexual behavior

567.06.text:
experts to coin this behavior now.
It's LUG: Meaning Lesbian Until Graduation.

578.90.text:
In describing these three categories, again it’s
important to point out that often times this

584.23.text:
woman would not consider herself a lesbian.
Often times she’s heterosexually attracted

589.98.text:
and would identify herself at heterosexual.
And often times perhaps her involvement with

595.16.text:
another woman is only temporary or in the case 
of emotionally enmeshed relationships, it's patterned.

602.80.text:
I want to spend a bit more
time though on the fourth variation – all

607.13.text:
four by the way can vary with regards to the
level of involvement, and I want to spend

612.26.text:
a little bit more time on the fourth one and
this would describe a woman the language we

618.02.text: would use that this is a Classic form of lesbian behavior and lesbian identity.

624.80.text: This describes a woman who strives to fulfill her emotional needs and her sexual desires solely in relationships

635.01.text:
with other women. She embraces the lesbian identity.
When she steps into that identity,

641.91.text:
the fullness of that identity, and she steps
into lesbian subculture, it brings this sense

647.22.text:
of freedom and relief of pleasure, empowerment,
comradery with other lesbian identified women

653.87.text:
-- obviously a level of intimacy. Women in
this category share often times that they

660.56.text:
have very little attraction to men or perhaps
none whatsoever. I can identify with that

667.86.text:
group thinking that’s where I fell when
I lived homosexually. As we try to unpack

676.00.text:
this and as Joe Dallas did with regard to
male homosexuality, as we try to unpack this

681.55.text:
struggle for women one of the things that
we would say is that for many women struggling

686.91.text:
with lesbianism, there is this type of yearning
in her heart if you will – this type of

693.50.text:
yearning in her heart for a sense of wholeness,
a sense of completion in her identity, in

700.67.text:
this relationship with another woman.
It's an inner driving need for acceptance and affirmation,

707.88.text:
for nurture, for love which I know that we can
all relate to and understand those are God

714.60.text:
given needs. When I lived homosexually, I
met those needs illegitimately obviously,

719.83.text:
but we understand those are God given needs.
At its core for a lot of women, one thing

726.65.text:
that we would say is that it doesn’t really
have anything to do with sex. That for women

731.92.text:
because how God has made us relationally,
how we’re intimately wired. So much for

737.22.text:
women it’s about connecting or more specifically
about connecting emotionally with another woman.

745.00.text:
And so it’s that need to connect
emotionally, now catch this language, it’s

750.60.text:
that need to connect emotionally that then
can later develop into a sexual expression.

758.17.text:
And so we’d like to try to flip the language
if you will. Instead of referring to it as

764.01.text:
homosexuality we prefer to refer to it as
homo-emotionality – emotional needs at the

771.17.text:
core that then later develop into a sexual expression.
As Joe was giving us a picture about male

783.07.text:
homosexuality and he shared that it develops
progressively and it develops as an accumulation

789.92.text:
of a number of factors and again that the
same is true of female homosexuality.

796.40.text:
And one of the models Joe offered involved family
dynamics – either real or perceived –

803.22.text: the relational dynamics within the home.

808.70.text: And I want to pause here intentionally.

814.00.text: If you are the parent of a son or daughter who is struggling with homosexuality, you are not to blame for

824.10.text:
his or her struggle. As Christians we know
from the beginning chapters of Genesis that

830.97.text:
there is no such thing as a perfect parent/child
relationship. They’re no such thing as a

837.93.text:
perfect family. You know that your children
are unique, one of a kind. Much to your dismay

846.04.text:
one of the things that you cannot control
is your child’s perception. And what we

852.95.text:
have found with many men and women with this
struggle is that a lot is based on their perception

860.80.text:
of those family dynamics, those family relationships,
in his or her interpretations of life events.

868.95.text:
And I know this is a delicate area, please
know how much we pray for you and pray over this.

873.94.text:
And so as we talk about these possible
influencing factors relating to the family,

880.90.text:
please understand that I am never implying
that a mother and father do not love their daughter.

888.20.text:
I am implying that she may not have
accurately perceived your love or other aspects

897.67.text:
of the relationship. So trying to qualify
this a bit let’s look first at that mother/daughter

907.00.text:
relationship and understanding we’re limited
in time and would like to unpack this a bit more.

912.20.text:
But let’s look on a few point level
on the mother/daughter relationship. Now ideally

922.00.text:
this is true of baby boys as well, but ideally
that infant girls first couple of years of

927.88.text:
life are spent developing that deep and secure
bond with her primary care giver which again

934.69.text:
ideally is her mother. With that deep and
secure bond what happens is that it helps

941.61.text:
that little girl grow into a sense of healthy
personal identity. If you’ve done any reading

949.04.text:
on this, psychologists Eric Erickson calls
this “the development of basic trust.”

954.74.text:
And Christian author and teacher Leanne Payne
refers to this process as “coming into a

960.54.text:
sense of being.” And so with that foundation
laid, with that sense of personal identity

967.44.text:
grounded in that little girl’s heart if
you will, she’s got a good foundation in

972.33.text:
place for that continued emotional growth
and development. If however for a variety

979.66.text:
of reasons, real – perceived, not necessarily
intentionally – by and large not intentionally

986.35.text:
on the part of the mother by the way. 
If that little girl fails to come into that sense

991.41.text:
of personal identity – catch this language
– it may leave her vulnerable to an empty

997.22.text:
sense of – an inner sense of emptiness and
longing. And it’s that inner sense of emptiness

1004.60.text:
and longing that then may later emerge in
her life in a form of an overwhelming drive

1011.44.text:
to connect with and find her identity in another woman.
For some women perhaps that is one

1021.63.text:
of the pieces of her proverbial puzzle.
But again even if that is one of the pieces, keep

1028.36.text:
in mind the picture of the scale, and a combination
of multiple progressive accumulating factors.

1038.00.text:
In her book “Out of Egypt,” Jeanette Howard,
she talked with hundreds of women overcoming

1044.62.text:
lesbianism and as she interviewed the women
she found with some there were long term patterned

1052.65.text:
broken relationships between the mother and the 
daughter and she gave names to these descriptions

1058.46.text:
to these. One for example she called the Doormat
Relationship. Now what she meant by that was

1065.12.text:
that mom embodied these genuine qualities
of Christ oftentimes. These sincere true qualities

1073.80.text:
of Christ and that she was self-sacrificing,
always esteeming others more highly then herself.

1080.79.text:
What happened though again was daughter’s
perception was that daughter perceived her

1085.21.text:
mom as weak perhaps or ineffective or downtrodden.
She perceived mom as subject to the whims

1091.38.text:
of people in general or perhaps subject to
the whims of men in particular. And so the

1097.77.text:
daughter then did not identify with mom. Another
example that Jeanette saw emerge in her interviews

1106.13.text:
was what she called “The My Best Friend”
relationship. And what she meant by that was

1111.24.text:
that in the mothers own state of emotional
unhealthiness she was unable to meet the intimacy

1118.61.text:
needs of her daughter and in fact the mother
actually sought the care for her own needs

1125.20.text:
from her daughter in the relationship.
And as some women described this scenario they

1131.72.text:
felt like there was a role reversal and that
the daughter was the parent in the relationship,

1136.73.text:
that the daughter was having to be the caretaker
and the nurturer verses mom because of mom’s

1142.97.text:
reasons – understandable, often significant
reasons for her own emotional brokenness.

1150.43.text:
In the examples that we listed in your workbook,
again from Jeanette’s book, if there are

1155.52.text:
fractures in that relationship between mother
and daughter, those core emotional needs may

1160.92.text:
not be met – that intimately connect relationship
may not form. And so for some women, they felt

1167.65.text:
like there was more of a surface relationship
with mom rather than one of depth.

1172.80.text:
Rather than attachment between the two, they seemed
detached and then rather than that intimacy

1179.12.text:
– there’s the language again – rather
than that intimacy between the two of them

1183.00.text:
that she felt estranged. Ellie, a woman overcoming,
said “as I grew up I remember spending much

1190.20.text:
of my time observing my mother rather than
connecting with her emotionally.

1196.20.text:
I knew I was meant to feel more for her but because
we seemed disconnected -- there’s the language

1201.33.text:
again -- because we seemed disconnected from
one another I did not.” Lisa, a woman overcoming,

1209.80.text:
said “I always felt misunderstood by my
mom and that I could never measure up to her

1214.92.text:
expectations. There are no specific occasions
I can point to really – there was just this

1220.19.text:
pervading sense of displeasure.” Now again,
whether that’s real or whether that was

1225.97.text:
Lisa’s perception.  What happened regrettably
for some little girls to compound this existing

1233.55.text:
and ever-growing problem is that, now I’m
not the sharpest tool in the shed – you

1238.39.text:
probably clued into that about 30 seconds
into this deal – but again, public school,

1243.49.text:
educated in Kentucky – English is a second
language for us there by the way, but I may

1255.38.text:
not be the sharpest tool but I’ve learned
it hurts to be hurt whether you’re intentionally

1260.42.text:
hurt or you perceived that you’ve been hurt
– it hurts. And so regrettably what happened

1265.99.text:
is that the little girls perceiving the hurt
began to emotionally withdraw from mother

1272.76.text:
and began to detach from her. Those of you
who are counselors and therapists you know

1276.81.text:
the language – defensive detachment – and
so it’s just continuing to build this wall

1282.32.text:
between the two of them. Allison, a woman
overcoming, said “I withdrew from any affection

1288.66.text:
my mom tried to show my. I remember times
when she did reach out to me but because I

1295.48.text:
had already withdrawn from her emotionally
I could not receive it.” And so one piece

1303.12.text:
that we want to offer for consideration -- if
you’re a family who has a loved one living

1309.04.text:
lesbian to ask you to consider that in your
own journey, if you’re a woman who struggled

1313.64.text:
with same-sex attraction, consider that in
your own journey. We’re offering that if

1318.47.text:
a little girl, not definitely, not guaranteed,
not absolutely – if that little girl does

1324.80.text:
not form a close relationship with mom, she
may be vulnerable to this future sexual identity struggle.

1336.00.text:
But there’s going to be more pieces
to the puzzle even if that’s a piece.

1342.70.text:
Mothers, of course play a significant role in the life
of their child. It’s how God intended it to be.

1351.00.text:
And probably Christians better than
any other group of people understand how critical

1356.10.text:
father is in the home as well. We know that
they’re both necessary and fathers in the

1362.61.text:
raising of children, equally important as
mothers -- fathers as they’re raising their

1368.03.text:
sons and as they’re raising their daughters.
Again we know there’s no such thing as a

1374.75.text:
perfect family, no such thing as a perfect
parent/child relationship.

1380.24.text:
There are four things in this ideal world
that a father would convey to his daughter

1386.53.text:
as she’s growing up. Those four things are
Protection, Attention, Adoration and Support.

1397.00.text:
Protection, Attention, Adoration and Support.
If a father is physically present and the

1405.70.text:
daughter knows that he is present in her life and
able to convey those four things, three really

1412.86.text:
important things happen as a result.
1: That little girl begins to grow into a sense of

1421.61.text:
worth in her personhood. So make the connection -- 
Worth and Personhood. Second: Because father

1431.37.text:
specifically because he’s the opposite sex,
he helps to begin to instill within her a

1437.55.text:
sense of value specifically in the fact that she’s female.
So Worth is Personhood and now Value is Female.

1446.80.text:
And then third it leaves for a season of her life
he represents this universal world of masculinity.

1455.80.text:
Some women either because
of real situations, some of them often times

1459.89.text:
noble, and that dad was working two or three
jobs to care for the family. Regrettably he

1465.58.text:
was absent from her life. Or some daughters
it was the misperception and so regrettably

1470.84.text:
the converse happened. She didn’t grow into
that sense of worth in her personhood, she

1476.83.text:
didn’t know that value specifically in the
fact that she’s female and she may have

1481.69.text:
felt inhibited or awkward or inadequate in
ways that she began to interact with the opposite sex.

1492.00.text:
A real or perceived unprotecting father
for example may not be able to instill within

1498.77.text:
his daughter that sense of security in safe
keeping. If a father – he may inadvertently

1505.53.text:
wound his daughter’s sense of value if he
doesn’t reflect back to her, her worth and

1511.16.text:
honor as a female. And some little girls for
example didn’t know that growing up as a

1517.04.text:
little girl is a wonderful and special thing.
Susan shared a story about the first time

1523.27.text:
that she went to a school dance before High
School and she said “although I usually

1529.51.text:
wore just blue jeans and a T-Shirt I decided
to dress up for this dance.” Now in Kentucky

1535.76.text:
we would say “kick that up a notch.”
I don’t know if that translates where you’re from.

1539.48.text:
You know in Kentucky, we dress up to
go to Wal-Mart and so – big hair and a nice

1545.24.text:
suit to go to Wal-Mart. It’s a whole other
world. But she said “I usually wore just

1552.39.text:
blue jeans and a T-Shirt and I decided to
dress up for this dance. Well not owning any

1556.79.text:
makeup myself I borrowed my mothers. The application
process was difficult. How on earth do women

1566.46.text:
manage to do this every day? Timidly I proceeded
down the stairs – dad I asked, how do I look?

1575.80.text:
And my father casually glanced up from
his evening newspaper, briefly examined my

1579.82.text:
appearance and then smirked, well who in the
world hit you in the eyes? My dad may have

1587.13.text:
been teasing but his words hurt my feelings.
I felt like my budding femininity was wounded.

1593.07.text:
I ran back to the bathroom with tears streaming
down my cheeks and scrubbed my face until

1597.89.text:
it was raw and I vowed I will never, ever,
ever, do that again.” And guess what, she didn't.

1611.20.text:
Now for some little girls temperament
comes into play, that might have been water

1615.96.text:
off a ducks back and she was wired with a
different temperament and that day for her

1623.55.text:
was symbolic. It was like – women, you know
this – omanious world of womanhood and femininity,

1628.45.text:
my gracious. And so it was this risk if you
will of trying to step into that world and

1633.70.text:
really needed her father’s affirmation at
that point and in his defense just felt uncomfortable

1640.37.text:
with his baby girl growing up and just didn’t
know what to say. We don’t know all the

1644.02.text:
dynamics obviously but regrettably the words
did wound and she withdrew then from what

1650.38.text:
that represented to her as far as stepping
out into that world of womanhood and femininity.

1662.74.text:
The relationship in the home between mom and
dad if they’re still married. That may be

1669.28.text:
an influencing role for some women and in
her perception of what it may mean one day

1676.50.text:
herself to be a wife and a mother. And so
it may affect her in regards to her gender

1681.14.text:
identity as well as these roles that perhaps
she’ll take on one day as wife and mother.

1687.14.text:
I think that women tend to be a little bit
more relationally intuitive than most men

1692.93.text:
and little girls often times are keenly observant
to mom and dad and then as she’s growing

1699.56.text:
up keenly observant to mom and dad and how
they relate to and treat one another.

1705.60.text:
One woman described her parents as indifferent
meaning that when they were together they

1709.81.text:
didn’t show love and affection and appreciation
for one another. Other women commented that

1715.90.text:
their mom’s critical comments about her
dad negatively affected her view of men and

1721.46.text:
their roles as husband and father. Other women
felt that because their father was minimizing

1727.88.text:
of their mother in the home her roles in the
family were subsequently devalued. Megan shared,

1734.84.text:
“I wanted to know the strength and joy and
beauty of my parents love for one another

1738.84.text:
but I never saw that and as such I did not
desire marriage, I did not aspire to become

1745.10.text:
a wife or a mother. You notice the stressing
– family dynamics can be based on real situations.

1754.08.text:
My gracious, divorce is real, abuse in a home
is real, the death of a parent is real or

1761.29.text:
sometimes so much of the struggle based on
misperceptions. The challenge though is that

1766.00.text:
the results can be the same. A breakdown in an
emotional bonding process between the daughter

1772.90.text:
and the mother may leave -- and catch this language -- 
may create a same-sex love deficit in that

1781.90.text:
daughter’s heart and at puberty that same
sex love deficit becomes sexualized.

1789.36.text:
And so one way then to look at lesbian relationships
for some women is that it’s this unconscious

1795.51.text:
attempt to restore what was missing in that
mother/daughter relationship. And then we

1802.68.text:
talked about what may be the affects if father for real
or perceived reasons is not as present in her life.

1821.20.text:
A next big piece: The occurrence of sexual abuse
among lesbian identified women is disproportionately

1833.00.text:
high when compared to national estimates of
sexual abuse against women in general.

1839.70.text:
Now a commonly used statistic states that 17 to
25 percent of US women will be sexually violated

1848.61.text:
at some point in her lifetime which is a horrific
statistic in and of itself. In the interviews

1855.45.text:
that Anne Paulk conducted for her book “Restoring
Sexual Identity – Hope For Women With Same-Sex

1860.80.text:
Attraction,” 66 percent of the women experienced
childhood sexual abuse. According to Doctor

1869.53.text:
Stanton Jones, the Provost of Wheaton College
and author of the book “Homosexuality – The

1874.08.text:
use of Scientific Research in the Churches
Moral Debate” – “Experience of sexual

1878.95.text:
abuse as a child more than tripled the likelihood
of later reporting homosexual orientation.”

1887.20.text:
Drawing from personal experience almost a
decade that I was on staff and then directed

1892.47.text:
an Exodus Member Ministry, I never met one
woman who had not been sexually threatened

1899.65.text:
or sexually violated. In almost a decade of
ministry I never met one woman who didn’t

1906.54.text:
have the trauma in her life and I didn’t
meet one man either who had not been sexually

1912.65.text:
seduced or violated. We gave you some other
statistics in your workbook – 85 percent

1919.42.text:
were violated by a man, a quarter of the women
were molested more than once and of course

1924.95.text:
same-sex violation takes place. 17 percent
of those sexually violated were seduced by

1929.96.text:
another female. If you’ve lived through
that trauma yourself, you know that sexual

1935.85.text:
abuse results in both initial and long term
adverse consequences on a survivor’s emotional

1943.33.text:
development and behavior. Doctor David Finkelhor,
he’s a leading US researcher in the area

1951.00.text:
of child sexual abuse and he describes some
of the consequences. “Guilt, shame, anxiety,

1958.21.text:
lowered self-esteem, depression, vulnerability
to drug and alcohol abuse, impaired ability

1964.18.text:
to judge the trustworthiness of others, confusion
between care getting and care giving, confusion

1971.25.text:
about sexual identity and sexual norms and
an inability to differentiate sex from love.”

1981.10.text:
Again, in this area of ministry for almost
15 years it comes as no surprise to me that

1987.14.text:
many women who have been sexually violated
have done several things. One, they have rejected

1993.78.text:
their identity as a woman because it’s a
liability to be a woman. Secondly, they’ve

2001.00.text:
shunned men – understandably the fear for
a lot of women even in intense hatred and

2006.48.text:
they shun men and then they turn exclusively
to women instead for relationships.

2013.97.text:
Do you know, one of the reasons I tried to look like
a man when I lived homosexually? It was my

2019.49.text:
suit of armor to keep me safe, to keep me
protected, to keep me from being hurt and

2027.19.text:
violated again. We know that Rosie O’Donnell
is extremely outspoken about her lesbian identity.

2033.73.text:
She wrote in her book Find Me “I was an
abused kid; I thought I had dealt with the

2038.19.text:
fallout in therapy and how naïve I was. Abuse
is often an ongoing saga for everyone who

2044.47.text:
has lived through it. It may start and stop
in real time but in mind time it seems never-ending.”

2056.66.text:
And we know that even something as traumatic
as sexual abuse that the Lord Jesus heals

2062.36.text:
and restores, Amen? Ellen DeGeneres – she
shared in the April 2005 edition of Allure

2068.90.text:
magazine, talked about the sexual abuse that
she suffered at the hands of her stepfather.

2075.75.text:
And I know it’s the wrong crowd to say this
to and understanding someone’s struggle

2080.26.text:
that oftentimes there’s hurt behind the
person, we hope that it solicits more empathy

2086.63.text:
and compassion and grace. I’ve eluded to
this a bit and that women with this struggle

2096.66.text:
have oftentimes made a number of misperceptions
about gender and what it means herself to

2103.19.text:
be a woman. And then what does it mean that
men are men. Remember, regardless of what’s

2110.05.text:
true and not true her perception becomes her
reality. With regard to their perception of

2116.36.text:
women in their roles, drawing from Anne’s
interviews again she asked the women --

2120.20.text:
"did you want to be like your mother when you were
growing up?” and 80 percent responded No.

2126.55.text:
She asked them, growing up which gender seemed
to have more desirable characteristics to be like?

2131.00.text:
A disproportionate number – 75
percent said the men were the more desirable

2136.06.text:
role models. Shocked by that high number she
asked why? The woman said that men are strong

2141.87.text:
and in control, not easily pushed around,
there less likely to be victimized. And their

2147.18.text:
perception was that men are valued and esteemed
more highly than women. 90 percent of the women

2154.40.text:
in Anne’s interviews identified themselves
as tomboys in childhood. 60 percent were mistaken

2159.90.text:
for boys as children. When she asked them
what are your perception of men? Some of the

2164.90.text:
comments they made: Men care only about themselves,
All that men want is sex, Men cannot be trusted,

2170.33.text:
Men are womanizers and A man can never love
me like a woman can. Now that may be true

2176.83.text:
of some men, I’m not going to put my dog
in that fight. But of course that’s not

2185.37.text:
true of all men. But again it’s what’s
happened to her and the people around her.

2193.24.text:
And then she begins to make these generalizations
about all men based perhaps on how a few have

2199.09.text:
treated her. Her perception regardless of
whether it’s true becomes her reality.

2209.47.text:
Joe mentioned this as well – peer issues.
Oh the joy of childhood. And whether intentional

2220.41.text:
or unintentional we know that in our growing
up years that peers exert a tremendous amount

2227.47.text:
of influence over us either in their rejection
or acceptance of us. Joe mentioned this about

2234.30.text:
men that it’s similar for women that often
time’s women growing up and as little girls,

2240.76.text:
as young women, she had this sense of feeling
different. As other young women began blossoming

2246.34.text:
into young womanhood, as she compared herself
to them, she didn’t feel like in her own

2251.73.text:
estimation that she measured up. And women
have given language to it – Third Sex mentality

2258.06.text:
– third sex mentality. What she means by
that is that she knows she’s not a man but

2263.71.text:
she doesn’t feel like she fits into the
world of women either and so it’s that third

2269.35.text:
sex mentality. And so what happens then is
that may tap into this inner sense of rejection

2275.83.text:
she may already be experiencing and so now
she withdraws even more, isolates and secludes

2281.63.text:
herself even more and so now she’s not spending
time with that additional community of people,

2287.33.text:
her same-sex peers who are necessary for her
ongoing growth and development in her gender

2292.74.text:
identity as a young woman. So you can see
the compounding effect of one piece to the

2298.72.text:
next piece to the next piece. And then finally
a major component, again this is related to

2309.20.text:
things we’ve already been talking about,
but as we really get down into the soil of

2314.94.text:
her heart and we see oftentimes for women
that she’s made dozens and dozens of judgments

2322.10.text:
and inner vows in her heart about herself
-- about herself as a woman, about the roles

2328.01.text:
of wife and motherhood, about men, the roles
of men, about marriage, sexuality.

2334.00.text: Oftentimes she makes these judgments -- she’s unaware of that she’s made them. Oftentimes again

2340.39.text:
they are in response to these life events
happening to her and around her.

2346.80.text:
And unaware of these seeds if you will, that are taking
root in her heart. And to try to make this

2354.24.text:
practical let’s just look at one piece,
the sexual abuse piece, and women who have

2360.18.text:
been sexually abused, these were some of the
judgments they formed in their hearts.

2364.70.text:
I'll never trust a man, I’ll never let a man
get close to me, I’ll never be emotionally

2369.37.text:
vulnerable to a man, I’ll never get married.
Oh I’m sorry, those are inner vows.

2374.02.text:
Let me jump back. On judgments when the women
talk about judgments they made about themselves

2379.37.text:
or about men again these roles – sexuality.
Some of the judgments the women made were:

2384.60.text: Being a woman is bad, Women are weak, Men only want sex, or that Men cannot be trusted.

2390.90.text: And so these decisions, these opinions, these judgments she makes in her heart as a result of being

2395.97.text:
sexually abused. And then as I was mentioning
kind of a fallout of judgments are what we

2401.47.text:
call inner vows where she makes these conclusive
decisions about what she’ll do or not do.

2408.38.text:
And again often times she’s unaware she’s
even making these in her heart. And so looking at

2413.37.text:
just at that piece of sexual abuse again,
some of the vows perhaps she made.

2418.40.text:
I'll never trust a man, I’ll never let a man
touch me again, never be emotionally vulnerable

2422.60.text:
to a man, I’ll never get married, never
be a wife, never be a mother. What is left?

2430.45.text:
What’s left? If you begin to make these
judgments, these vows and as I worked through

2438.10.text:
this in my own life I had page after page
after page of these and they literally were

2444.46.text:
restricting me, binding me to think and feel
and only behave in agreement with those judgments

2452.40.text:
or with those vows. You can imagine the freedom
when God broke through those. Those are some

2463.87.text:
of the major pieces that we’ve seen, not
in every woman’s life. Maybe some were applicable

2469.89.text:
to some woman and some aren’t. It’s what
we’ve seen in a disproportionate number

2474.72.text:
of women’s lives and asking you to consider those.
And then some secondary factors – touched

2481.08.text:
on this – the positive portray of homosexuality
and lesbianism in the mainstream media.

2486.10.text:
Some women went away to school, secular colleges,
were exposed to radical feminist ideologies

2494.48.text:
or ideologies depending on your part of the
country, not biblical femininity but these

2500.05.text:
radical feminist ideologies. We talked about
personality temperament. Some dynamics would

2506.67.text:
have no effect on one young woman but would
greatly influence perhaps another young woman

2512.05.text:
given her temperament. Maybe negative experiences
with boyfriends growing up or problems within

2518.26.text:
a marriage. Goodness knows that most 15 year
old young men don’t exactly epitomize healthy

2526.00.text:
Christian masculine maturity – no more needs
to be said there. Loneliness: Women, we know,

2537.46.text:
we’re especially susceptible to loneliness
in ways that we'll reach out and need to have

2545.30.text:
that need met and sometimes relationships
that started out very healthy and then that

2550.68.text:
great need, that chasm if you will of loneliness
and how a healthy relationship then began

2557.25.text:
to stray and cross boundaries. Some women,
their desire for a son – she was a single

2563.49.text:
child and so her parents desired a son verses
a daughter and the rippling fallout effect

2570.06.text:
in that type of relational dynamic. And then
certainly as Christians who hold to a biblical

2576.24.text:
world view, we believe in the spiritual component
that we’re conceived and born in sin, that

2583.44.text:
God’s adversary is the father of lies, that
he plans schemes against our lives. And we

2590.33.text:
don’t talk as much about the spiritual component
at Love Won Out Conferences because we assume

2595.50.text:
as Christians we’re already on that same
proverbial page. We understand that’s one

2601.27.text:
of these influencing factors and don’t flesh
that out as much again assuming that we believe

2607.17.text: that Christian world view, that spiritual component.

2611.69.text:
When we started I asked you to keep in your
mind that picture of a scale, right?

2616.70.text:
And the cause and effect relationship that one side
has over the other all related to that degree

2622.93.text:
of weight or influence. We don’t believe
that people are born gay. We believe that

2630.45.text:
same-sex attraction results again from this
accumulation and this complex interaction

2637.17.text:
of multiple factors, multiple influencing
factors as such as those that Joe outlined this

2647.03.text:
I want to wind the clock back a number of
years to the mid-later 50’s when this very

2654.88.text:
cute and vibrant young woman of 18 met this
very handsome and dashing young man of 23

2665.07.text:
who had just been honorably discharged from
the Navy. And that young man and that young

2672.99.text:
woman full of life, vibrant met and they very
quickly fell in love and became husband and wife.

2681.60.text:
Ohhhhhh.. Don’t you love a “love story?"
Because adoption was the only way

2693.59.text:
that that young couple could have children.
I’m so grateful to be the second child that

2702.12.text:
was birthed in their heart because the heart
is a womb as well, Amen? I’m proud to be

2711.21.text:
a southern girl, I’m sorry for the twang
and the drawl. Proud to be a southern girl

2716.48.text:
and grew up in Kentucky. 42 years later my
parents still live in the same home and my

2723.92.text:
big brother Bill and his family live just
a few miles down the road. I grew up going

2730.86.text:
to church. Trinity Presbyterian was just a couple
of miles from our home and at Trinity I was

2737.85.text:
baptized as a baby and went to vacation Bible
school in the summers and much to the chagrin

2744.57.text:
of my pastors wife I played in the children’s
hand bell choir – and I’m not musically gifted.

2763.20.text: There’s a Sunday morning that stands out --

2765.58.text:
I was 13 years old at the time sitting
in the churches sanctuary nestled between

2770.60.text:
my mom and dad waiting for the service to
begin and I casually picked up a Bible that

2775.79.text:
was resting on the back of the pew in front
of me and began to flip through the pages at random.

2782.80.text:
It fell open to the book of Leviticus
– the 18th chapter of Leviticus and my eyes

2792.14.text:
fell upon verse 22: “A man should not lie
with another man as one lies with a woman

2797.78.text:
– semicolon – that is detestable.”
My eyes darted to the beginning of the verse

2807.70.text:
and I read it again more slowly. My eyes hung
on that semicolon and then swung to the words

2813.46.text:
that followed – that is detestable.
I only read Leviticus 18 – 22 twice that Sunday

2822.73.text:
morning but my subsequent decision would have
far reaching and tragic consequences.

2830.40.text:
When I read the verse I misunderstood it. I thought
the words after the semicolon read Melissa

2838.77.text:
is detestable and so I closed that Bible,
placed it back on the pew in front of me and

2847.37.text:
almost symbolic now as I look back, I also
closed my heart to God because I had misread

2854.50.text:
the verse and I thought that that’s what
He was saying about me. That even at 13 was

2860.43.text:
already questioning whether I might be gay,
was already questioning my sexual identity

2866.29.text:
and it felt like a seed, a seed was beginning
to take root in the soul of my heart.

2876.26.text:
As my pre-teen years began to unfold I had all these
questions in my mind, this all-encompassing

2881.99.text:
question of what is wrong with me and why
am I not attracted to the boys like the other girls?

2890.70.text:
Why do I hate being a girl, why do
I wish I could have been born a boy instead.

2895.62.text:
And this all-encompassing question of what’s
wrong with me. And so I went to a dictionary

2901.26.text:
one day and read the definitions to words
like lesbian and queer and gay and homosexual

2907.31.text:
and then that seed sprouted. Freshman year
of high school, the last time that I dated.

2916.33.text:
One day a young man named Ted handed me a note
in between classes and I’ll never forget

2922.00.text:
that note because it was the tiniest, most
compact note I’d ever seen and it looked

2926.39.text:
like a little piece of white chicklet gum
and he had skilfully secured that note with

2933.14.text:
a Band-Aid adhesive – ingenious young man.
And on the inside of the note he’d written

2940.24.text:
Melissa, will you be my girlfriend -- 
check one box below. True story. Yes or no.

2959.25.text:
And I checked the No box and I refolded the note
and I slipped it in his locker that afternoon

2967.50.text:
and now I had closed my heart to the opposite sex.
I was 16 when I became involved in my

2975.60.text:
first homosexual relationship and that was
kind of what marked the beginning of the next

2979.83.text:
10 years of my life unaware and unable and
unwilling to resist that temptation and that draw --

2991.06.text:
I embraced and welcomed that lesbian identity.
When I left home at 18 to attend

2997.64.text:
college I immersed myself in that identity,
immersed myself in the gay and lesbian community

3004.26.text:
and everything in my world revolved around
being gay and that seed flourished.

3015.00.text: The Bible says that God does not want anyone to perish, but everyone to come to repentance.

3026.00.text:
And so in the mid-later 80’s I was working for
the advertising agency in Kentucky that was

3031.21.text:
owned by three men -- a rich man, a Jewish man,
and a Christian man. Sounds like a setup

3042.72.text:
to a joke, doesn’t it? True. Bill Martinez
was the Christian man. I knew that Bill was

3056.25.text:
a Christian and I knew that Bill knew I was
living homosexually and because I presumed

3063.06.text:
to know what Christians thought of gays and lesbians
I expected Bill to judge me and to treat me poorly

3073.00.text:
-- and he never did. Without exception he always
showed me compassion and grace and kindness.

3084.50.text:
He always respected me as a person
both professionally and personally and so

3091.70.text:
after a while our casual conversations would
gravitate to spiritual issues and although

3099.00.text:
I had grown-up in the church I had never accepted
Jesus Christ as my personal savior and so

3106.63.text:
in time, something spiritual began to stir
in my heart. And so one Saturday night I asked

3118.48.text:
my live in lesbian partner of several years
if she wanted to go to church the next morning.

3125.48.text:
(Laughter…) Yeah. She said yes.
She'd grown up Catholic, I’d grown up going to

3142.27.text:
a Presbyterian church but we’d been away
from church for a long, long time. So we didn’t

3148.11.text:
know where to go so we opened the phone book
and looked at the church listings in the Yellow

3151.94.text:
pages of that phone book and again Kentucky
school educated, it was about three hours

3156.00.text:
before we got to the letter “C” but we
worked our way through. What comes after B?

3160.67.text:
I don’t know what. And we saw there listed
in those yellow pages the churches and because

3168.21.text:
I’d grown up Presbyterian that seemed familiar
and comfortable and where we were living,

3172.32.text:
a small Bible belt community in Kentucky,
there was one Presbyterian Church.

3178.20.text:
And so the next morning we put on our Sunday best
– you all say that where you’re from – put

3182.51.text:
on your Sunday best? We drove the three blocks
to church, we parked, we nervously walked

3190.44.text:
into the sanctuary and inconspicuously slid
into a back pew. And we sat there only a few

3198.14.text:
minutes before we surmised two very important things
about this church. It was a small congregation of

3210.00.text:
predominately older couples. The median age was 70 --
I kid you not -- and you have picture that for a minute.

3237.80.text: You have to picture two lesbian identified women sitting

3241.36.text:
in a small community church with a lot of
precious blue hairs and to say that we stood

3247.23.text:
out in an understatement. I still can’t
find the words to describe how they treated

3254.24.text:
us on Sunday morning. With an unexpected kindness
and a tender warmth and so overwhelmed by

3266.59.text:
their friendliness we showed up the next Sunday
and the next Sunday and the next Sunday and

3272.59.text:
before I knew it I was going to Wednesday
night potluck dinners and this adult Sunday

3278.63.text:
morning Bible study and much of the chagrin
of the pastors wife I joined the adult hand bell choir.

3299.00.text:
Bless her soul, she’s recovering too, I know.
And there was a precious couple in this church,

3307.40.text:
Doris and L.J. Crain who took me into their
spiritual care and knit me into their hearts.

3315.00.text:
You have to understand that Bill from my workplace
and Doris and L.J. knew I was living homosexually.

3322.27.text:
I mean that had God’s discerning spirit,
they were mature Christians and one look at

3328.26.text:
me and they assumed that I’m sure given
the masculine and the mannish appearance – you

3333.11.text:
know, I’ll make this side comment and I’m
probably more serious than joking – the

3337.61.text:
fact that I show up here every day in a skirt
and panty hose and high heel shoes is like

3341.90.text:
a testimony in and of itself, so we had – thank
you Lord. We had no other little part of the

3349.72.text:
testimony that would be sufficient. And Bill
and Doris and L.J. knew exactly how I was

3356.89.text:
living and they met me where I was, accepted
me with grace, loved me unconditionally and

3365.74.text:
prayed for me fervently and it was because
of relationship with them that one afternoon

3374.38.text:
sitting alone in my bedroom on the edge of
my bed I said that prayer that I trust most

3380.56.text:
of you have made and if you haven’t, one
day you’ll make, when I said quietly in

3386.96.text:
my heart, Jesus would you come and be savior
of my soul and Lord of my life and He did.

3399.27.text:
And he put a new seed down in my heart.
Do you know my lesbian partner actually gave

3406.73.text:
me my first Bible, I don’t know where that
lines up with your theology, we’re an eclectic

3415.43.text:
group I know. It was the New International
Version Study Bible in blue leather with silver

3422.22.text:
edged pages and the words of Jesus in red.
I began to read that Bible and it wasn’t

3428.40.text:
long before I discovered what a concordance
is – that’s handy!! In case this ever

3436.69.text:
comes up, dinner conversation, you’re playing
Bible trivia, in the NIV Study Bible concordance,

3442.20.text:
homosexuality is listed alphabetically in between
home town and honesty, so if you ever need that.

3454.50.text:
And of course you know there are a number
of scriptures listed. Leviticus I had ready

3463.22.text:
so many years before, we know Romans, I Corinthians,
I Timothy. And as I began to read those verses

3473.65.text:
it was like a wrestling match began with God.
Because my faith was so new I couldn’t yield

3481.72.text:
to those truths yet and so I argued with Him
and I debated and I ran from Him and rebelled

3489.16.text:
against Him. These very raw conversations
with Him on many a day of God, I didn’t

3496.30.text:
ask for these feelings, I don’t know where
they’ve come from, I never remember choosing them,

3505.00.text:
I don’t know how not to have them,
I don’t know how to get rid of them.

3510.00.text:
I don't know how beyond that to be attracted to men.
I can’t imagine if I could ever be a wife

3516.64.text:
or a mother, I don’t know where to go from
here, I don’t know what to do.

3522.00.text: But these two things now that I know, that I know that You are real and that Your word is true.

3530.80.text:
You all know scripture teaches that the word of God
is living and active, that it’s sharper than

3537.25.text:
a double edged sword that it penetrates even
to dividing soul and spirit and joints and marrow.

3543.80.text:
How it judges the thoughts and attitudes
of the heart. I love Isaiah 55:11 how it says

3551.33.text:
of God’s word; that it will not return empty,
but it will accomplish what God desires and

3557.42.text:
achieve those purposes for which He sends it.
And so what happened was that over the

3563.08.text:
next four months and over the next eight months
and over the next twelve months, God kept

3568.62.text:
working that truth a little bit deeper and
a little bit deeper and a little bit deeper

3573.64.text:
until you come to that day, that convicting
revelatory day where it’s done so precisely

3579.48.text:
and done yet so gently where you know that what
you’re doing is wrong but God had demonstrated

3585.52.text:
His own love for me in this that while I was
still a sinner, that Christ had died for me.

3591.13.text:
And you know scripture teaches that it’s
God’s kindness that leads us to repentance

3596.15.text:
and that repentance is a gift. And in those
wilderness months and that rebellious rage

3601.53.text:
and that defiant disobedience my Father persistently
perused with that passionate love and kept wooing,

3608.55.text:
come home sweetheart, come home sweetheart,
come home sweetheart. And it was 1992, anniversary

3616.47.text:
month in October where the lights went on
if you will and I knew the sin that I was

3621.71.text:
living in and He ministered that repenting
grace and then that new seed sprouted.

3635.70.text:
We plan our course but God orders our steps.
And in time He connected me with Exodus International

3644.26.text:
and they’re exhibiting this weekend and
their member ministries and by His grace there

3649.41.text:
was an Exodus Member Ministry where I was
living and connected with them and then through

3654.26.text:
Exodus and Christian counselors and mentors
and friends and slowly began to uncover and

3661.60.text:
work through the many and varied factors that had
contributed to my own struggle with same-sex attraction.

3669.80.text:
And needless to say the complexity
of the struggle that it took so long and I

3676.52.text:
don’t know what is forthcoming but I’m
assuming at this junction in the journey that

3680.54.text:
it’s the most painful and the most difficult
that perhaps I’ll go through and it is a

3687.01.text:
journey that I would never hesitate to take
again because better is one day in the Lord’s

3709.42.text:
If you’re believers it’s probably not
surprising that that most sobering and solemn time

3716.73.text:
in that journey of recovery was when I had
to face the weightiness and the extent of

3725.26.text:
my sin and I had to begin to acknowledge all
the people against whom I had sinned, most

3734.80.text:
importantly my family and my God. You know
Jacob Spanier called the Father of Pietism,

3744.68.text:
what he said of sin: “We must call to memory
that is was our sins, that is mine and yours,

3751.71.text:
which brought such great suffering to the Lord.
Our sins were the whips, the thorns,

3757.11.text:
the fists, the nails, which wounded the Lord
and mistreated Him in His suffering.”

3763.80.text: And in confessing my sin I was showered in God’s merciful forgiveness and made clean through the blood of the Lamb.

3773.60.text:
My parents learned I was gay when I was 19
and understandably they were heartbroken and

3780.60.text:
disappointed and rightly so. They never accepted
my involvement in homosexuality and they loved

3788.97.text:
me unconditionally and I will be forever grateful
for their unending and unconditional love.

3800.10.text:
About four ago they made a profession of faith
and were baptized. Now we’re together in God's family.

3815.00.text:
The most important part of
the journey was learning about the Holy Trinity

3819.80.text:
and beginning to cultivate a relationship
with each person, that mystery of three God's in one.

3830.00.text:
And beginning to cultivate the Fathers
initiation, that relationship between father

3835.40.text:
and daughter – father and child and I mean
this so reverently and adoringly that now

3841.00.text:
He's is my papa, my tender papa. And in the Holy
Spirit as revealer of truth, of counselor,

3852.25.text:
of enabler for all that’s impossible and
a comforter. And as he began to cultivate

3861.05.text:
that relationship with His Son, Jesus.
His tender savior, this awesome Lord and majestic King

3876.80.text:
and then pushed out all the broken and counterfeit
love and filled instead with His divine and perfect love.

3891.97.text:
And then He began to teach me about
this thing called womanhood, oh my gosh!!

3903.20.text:
Who knew there was so much to learn? And who
knew how expensive it is to be a woman and

3922.22.text:
all the gadgets that marketers have created
to try to accentuate our beauty. A few years

3928.40.text:
ago one of my coworkers encouraged me to purchase
a heated eyelash curler. Who even knew such

3938.99.text:
a think existed as a heated eyelash curler?
She bought in QVC and she said Melissa you

3946.07.text:
ought to get you one of these and I said Linda,
I would burn my forehead off!!

3952.60.text:
And then she got tickled and said well then you’d be
a “Fry forehead” as well as a “Fry rear.”

3961.00.text:
I was not amused. Oh and it’s a journey.
And so then as the Father helped heal and

3976.22.text:
restore my identity as a woman and that this
is good daughter, this is wonderful, there’s

3982.25.text:
a joy in this, celebrate this. As He brought
me into that place then He began to open up

3989.46.text:
my eyes and my heart to the opposite sex.
(Purring noise) Now I am single but I’m expecting

4004.23.text:
or, expecting -- oh, I like – that could
be a prophetic word, I meant to say accepting

4008.40.text:
but I said expecting – a marriage proposal.
Why are you laughing?? So you’ve got to

4018.80.text:
help me out. Keep your eyes open for a tall
red haired man, late 30’s to the early 50’s

4023.34.text:
who loves football and would look good in
a Scottish kilt. I might have to scrap that

4039.76.text:
because I’m enjoying the company of a wonderful
man about a year and a half now. A good Englishman,

4045.55.text:
not the Scotsman but a wonderful Englishman
and we’re both enjoying ourselves and not

4052.48.text:
sure what God’s up to yet, but if there’s
a marriage, you’re all invited to the wedding.

4058.97.text:
Your will Father. And then a new seed begins
to bud. Ultimately though isn’t this journey

4066.26.text:
of overcoming sexual sin and sexual brokenness,
that journey that so many Christians are on.

4073.63.text:
If we really begin to unpack to the essentials,
it's an unwavering motivation to live your life

4080.42.text:
before God repentantly and obediently.  It's an 
unquenchable craving in your heart for holiness.

4090.60.text:
It’s an exchange of what you worship.
William Temple, the renowned Archbishop

4096.37.text:
of Canterbury said of worship “It is the
submission of our nature to God, the quickening

4102.52.text:
of conscience by His holiness, nourishment
of mind by His truth, purifying of imagination

4108.24.text:
by His beauty, opening of the heart to His
love, and submission of will to His purpose.

4115.26.text:
All this gathered up in adoration is the greatest
of all expressions of which we are capable.”

4125.20.text:
It’s a redemptive journey which we know
is the journey of every believer. Yes?

4132.90.text:
And then what does it ultimately boil down to?
Is that it’s a love relationship that you

4144.99.text:
become so captivated, so enthralled, so desperately
in love with your Lord that you hope your

4154.70.text:
heart will say; whatever You ask of me Lord,
Your will be done and not mine and that you

4164.48.text:
yield to Him and that you submit to Him because
you love Him. And we know that we only love

4171.99.text:
Him because He first loved us. I love “Amazing Grace"
and I love Charles Wesley’s hymn

4182.93.text:
“And can it be that I should gain.”
If you’re familiar with it my method as friends, the fourth stanza is my favorite.

4192.00.text: "Long my imprisoned sprit lay, fast bound in sin and natures night.

4206.80.text:
Thine eye diffused a quickening ray.
I woke in that dungeon flamed with light.

4216.30.text: My chains fell off, my heart was free, and I rose, went forth, and followed thee.”

4234.20.text: And that new seed flowers. I told you I was a crybaby.

4258.00.text: Acts 20:24 says, "I consider my life worth nothing to me, if only I may finish the race and complete

4268.60.text: the tasks the Lord Jesus has given me.  The task of testifying to the gospel of God's grace."

4279.50.text: In Jesus magnificint, beautiful, tender, life transforming name. To Him be all the glory, in Jesus name, Amen.
